SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on Pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you or may not apply at all. You may find it necessary to leave blank spaces. Use extra sheets to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

By train from New York to Chicago, then by boat to Minnesota.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

After arriving at Pembina we met many friendly Indians who gave us food and shelter. We also met the river and had to cross it several times.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They were not sure about it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I traveled with my family.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By train from New York to Chicago.

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We arrived at Minneola, Illinois, and then we traveled by train to Chicago. We then took a boat to St. Louis, Missouri, and then we traveled by train to Kansas City, Missouri. We then took a bus to Denver, Colorado, and then we traveled by train to Laramie, Wyoming. We then took a bus to Cheyenne, Wyoming, and then we traveled by train to Fort Benton, Montana. We then took a bus to Great Falls, Montana, and then we traveled by train to Calgary, Alberta, Canada.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At a friend's house.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

In a place called "The Homestead."

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We lived in Saskatchewan for 3 years.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I worked as a threshing machine operator in the railroad yard. After coming to Saskatchewan, I began farming.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They were not very pleased.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other groups)?

I traveled alone and had no help.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

I came on the train from New York.

14. What highlights of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

The trip was very long and tiring.

15. How many days after you arrived in Saskatchewan?

It took us about two weeks.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

I settled near Medicine Hat.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We lived in Medicine Hat for three years.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I worked as a laborer and then as a farmer. Since coming to Saskatchewan, I have been working as a farmer.
